results.title: Hey, That Red Carpet Isn’t Red!
results.abstract: The 2023 Academy Awards carpet’s champagne hue — a break with a 62-year tradition of the bright red rug — is the latest arrival rug to opt for a colorful palette.
org_facet: Academy of Television Arts and Sciences

multimedia.caption: Clockwise from left: The Emmy’s carpet in 2022; ‘Avatar: The Way of Water’ premiere in 2022; and the premiere of ”Black Panther: Wakanda Forever” in 2022; the Golden Globe Awards in 2023.

results.title: ‘Scream VI’ Review: Yes, Another Scary Movie
results.abstract: Ghostface and meta commentary are back in this sequel, yet the weight of obligations to the dictates of the franchise ultimately drags it down.

multimedia.caption: Melissa Barrera, left, and Jenna Ortega in “Scream VI.”
Melissa Barrera, left, and Jenna Ortega in “Scream VI.”
Melissa Barrera, left, and Jenna Ortega in “Scream VI.”

results.title: ‘65’ Review: What on Earth?
results.abstract: Millions of years ago, a guy from another planet landed on this one. Like most survivors, he had a moody little girl with him.

multimedia.caption: Adam Driver and Ariana Greenblatt in “65,” directed by Scott Beck and Bryan Woods.
Adam Driver and Ariana Greenblatt in “65,” directed by Scott Beck and Bryan Woods.
Adam Driver and Ariana Greenblatt in “65,” directed by Scott Beck and Bryan Woods.

results.title: Watch Scenes From These Eight Best Picture Nominees
results.abstract: Inventive and surprising moments happened in front of and behind the camera this awards season. Here’s a look at memorable sequences in the top contenders.

results.title: ‘Stonewalling’ Review: A Young Woman’s Exchange Value
results.abstract: In this haunting drama, a 20-year-old Chinese woman struggles to find her place in a country where she faces a series of seemingly impossible hurdles.

multimedia.caption: Huang Xiaoxiong, left, and Yao Honggui in “Stonewalling,” which takes place in Changsha, the capital of Hunan province.
Huang Xiaoxiong, left, and Yao Honggui in “Stonewalling,” which takes place in Changsha, the capital of Hunan province.
Huang Xiaoxiong, left, and Yao Honggui in “Stonewalling,” which takes place in Changsha, the capital of Hunan province.

results.title: To Perform ‘Hold My Hand,’ Lady Gaga Goes au Naturel
results.abstract: The artist wasn’t even set to take the stage. Instead she exchanged her initially glamorous look for a stripped-down one to suit her intense delivery.

multimedia.caption: Lady Gaga opting for a minimal look onstage.
Lady Gaga opting for a minimal look onstage.
Lady Gaga opting for a minimal look onstage.

results.title: Jamie Lee Curtis Wins Best Supporting Actress, Her First Oscar
results.abstract: “I know it looks like I’m standing up here by myself, but I am not. I am hundreds of people,” she said in her acceptance speech.

multimedia.caption: Jamie Lee Curtis savoring her victory on Sunday.
Jamie Lee Curtis savoring her victory on Sunday.
Jamie Lee Curtis savoring her victory on Sunday.

results.title: Jimmy Kimmel Addressed ‘the Slap’ in His Opening Monologue
results.abstract: Kimmel’s remarks also included joking jabs at some of Hollywood’s most famous figures.
results.byline: By Nancy Coleman and Matt Stevens

multimedia.caption: Jimmy Kimmel wasted little time acknowledging recent snafus at the Oscars, including Will Smith’s infamous slap of Chris Rock.
Jimmy Kimmel wasted little time acknowledging recent snafus at the Oscars, including Will Smith’s infamous slap of Chris Rock.
Jimmy Kimmel wasted little time acknowledging recent snafus at the Oscars, including Will Smith’s infamous slap of Chris Rock.

results.title: Ke Huy Quan Wins Best Supporting Actor Oscar, Capping a Remarkable Comeback
results.abstract: “My journey started on a boat. I spent a year in a refugee camp. And somehow, I ended up here on Hollywood’s biggest stage,” he said in his acceptance speech.

multimedia.caption: Ke Huy Quan accepting the Oscar for best supporting actor.
Ke Huy Quan accepting the Oscar for best supporting actor.
Ke Huy Quan accepting the Oscar for best supporting actor.

results.title: How the Slap Has Changed the Oscars
results.abstract: Here’s a look at the fallout from last year’s Oscars, when Will Smith slapped Chris Rock onstage.

Chris Rock, left, and Will Smith just after the Slap.

results.title: What Do You Think of the Oscars Show?
results.abstract: The Times invites readers to share their comments and observations about the 2023 Academy Awards.

results.title: Adam Brody Feels All the Feels With Surfing, ‘Avatar’ and Cate Le Bon
results.abstract: The “Shazam!” star revives himself with sprinkle doughnuts, Frank Black’s “Teenager of the Year” and daily naps.

multimedia.caption: Watching “The Way of Water” brought tears to Adam Brody’s eyes, he said, “and I haven’t cried at a movie since ‘Titanic.’”
Watching “The Way of Water” brought tears to Adam Brody’s eyes, he said, “and I haven’t cried at a movie since ‘Titanic.’”
Watching “The Way of Water” brought tears to Adam Brody’s eyes, he said, “and I haven’t cried at a movie since ‘Titanic.’”

results.title: Oscar-Nominated Film Depicts Road to Justice That Is ‘Permanently Alive’
results.abstract: “Argentina, 1985” has resurrected the country’s military rule, which ended 40 years ago. The quest persists to hold those accused of crimes against humanity accountable.
des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

multimedia.caption: Pictures of missing people at the Naval Mechanics School, also known as the ESMA, a former clandestine center for detention, torture and killings, in Buenos Aires.

results.title: Brett Goldstein Faces Life After ‘Lasso’
results.abstract: The Apple TV+ show’s breakout star is preparing to play a Marvel movie god when he’s not working on the hit streaming series “Shrinking.” But what he’s really after is human connection.

multimedia.caption: “I used to be very, very miserable and had a quite dark brain, and I’ve worked very hard at changing that,” Brett Goldstein said. “But it’s there.”
multimedia.copyright: Magdalena Wosinska for The New York Times

results.title: Five International Movies to Stream Now
results.abstract: This month’s picks include a Kafkaesque South Indian comedy, a delirious British noir caper scripted by Alan Moore and a Czech body-horror movie that’ll get under your skin.

multimedia.caption: Mammootty in “Nanpakal Nerathu Mayakkam.”
Mammootty in “Nanpakal Nerathu Mayakkam.”
Mammootty in “Nanpakal Nerathu Mayakkam.”

results.title: Five Children’s Movies to Stream Now
results.abstract: This month’s picks include a musical adaptation of a Roald Dahl classic, an animated coming-of-age story and an assortment of lovable farm animals.
des_facet: The Biggest Little Farm: The Return (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Emma Thompson, left, is a delicious villain as the school headmistress Agatha Trunchbull, with Alisha Weir as Matilda in “Roald Dahl’s Matilda the Musical.”

results.title: In ‘Scream VI,’ Ghostface Takes the 1 Train
results.abstract: In turning the subway into a vehicle of horror, the movie gets a number of things right — and a few wrong. But verisimilitude wasn’t the filmmakers’ main goal.

multimedia.caption: Ghostface on the subway in a scene from “Scream VI.”
Ghostface on the subway in a scene from “Scream VI.”
Ghostface on the subway in a scene from “Scream VI.”

results.title: ‘Chang Can Dunk’ Review: That’s a Man’s Jam
results.abstract: A short teen channels his inner Kobe Bryant in this exhilarating, warmhearted Disney+ basketball comedy.

multimedia.caption: From left, Zoey Renee, Bloom Li, Dexter Darden and Ben Wang in “Chang Can Dunk.”
From left, Zoey Renee, Bloom Li, Dexter Darden and Ben Wang in “Chang Can Dunk.”
From left, Zoey Renee, Bloom Li, Dexter Darden and Ben Wang in “Chang Can Dunk.”

results.title: Review: Jessica Chastain Plots an Escape From ‘A Doll’s House’
results.abstract: Jamie Lloyd’s compelling, surgically precise revival of Ibsen’s 1879 drama throbs like an episode of “CSI: Norway.”

multimedia.caption: Jessica Chastain and Arian Moayed as Nora and Torvald Helmer in “A Doll’s House” at the Hudson Theater. The modernized script, our critic writes, leaves the dialogue raw and red, as if exfoliated.
Jessica Chastain and Arian Moayed as Nora and Torvald Helmer in “A Doll’s House” at the Hudson Theater. The modernized script, our critic writes, leaves the dialogue raw and red, as if exfoliated.
Jessica Chastain and Arian Moayed as Nora and Torvald Helmer in “A Doll’s House” at the Hudson Theater. The modernized script, our critic writes, leaves the dialogue raw and red, as if exfoliated.

results.title: Robert Blake, ‘Baretta’ Star Acquitted in Wife’s Murder, Dies at 89
results.abstract: His film and TV career began with “Our Gang” comedies and was highlighted by his performance as a killer in “In Cold Blood.” But he led a tempestuous life.

multimedia.caption: Robert Blake in a scene from his 1970s television series “Baretta,” which ran for three years. He played a detective with a pet cockatoo named Fred.
Robert Blake in a scene from his 1970s television series “Baretta,” which ran for three years. He played a detective with a pet cockatoo named Fred.
Robert Blake in a scene from his 1970s television series “Baretta,” which ran for three years. He played a detective with a pet cockatoo named Fred.

results.title: Oscars 2023 Predictions: Who Will Win Best Picture, Actor and Actress?
results.abstract: “Everything Everywhere All at Once” is the favorite, but “All Quiet on the Western Front” could be a spoiler. Here’s how our expert is marking his ballot.

results.title: ‘99 Moons’ Review: On-Again, Off-Again
results.abstract: Instead of an engaging erotic romance, the film delivers a dull narrative of two lovers caught in a cycle of getting together and falling apart.

multimedia.caption: In “99 Moons,” Valentina Di Pace and Dominik Fellmann play lovers who repeatedly pursue each other, get together and then break up over misunderstandings.
In “99 Moons,” Valentina Di Pace and Dominik Fellmann play lovers who repeatedly pursue each other, get together and then break up over misunderstandings.
In “99 Moons,” Valentina Di Pace and Dominik Fellmann play lovers who repeatedly pursue each other, get together and then break up over misunderstandings.

results.title: ‘Punch’ Review: Hitting at the Heart
results.abstract: Welby Ings’s keenly observant debut feature follows a young, promising boxer whose priorities shift.

multimedia.caption: Jordan Oosterhof, left, and Tim Roth in “Punch.”
Jordan Oosterhof, left, and Tim Roth in “Punch.”
Jordan Oosterhof, left, and Tim Roth in “Punch.”

results.title: As a Film Revives Elvis’s Legacy, the Presleys Fight Over His Estate
results.abstract: After the death of Lisa Marie Presley, Elvis’s ex-wife initiated a legal battle with her granddaughter over control of the family trust.

multimedia.caption: Priscilla Presley, left, and her daughter, Lisa Marie Presley, flanking Austin Butler at the Golden Globe Awards in January.
Priscilla Presley, left, and her daughter, Lisa Marie Presley, flanking Austin Butler at the Golden Globe Awards in January.
Priscilla Presley, left, and her daughter, Lisa Marie Presley, flanking Austin Butler at the Golden Globe Awards in January.

results.title: ‘Unicorn Wars’ Review: Teddy Bears in Battle
results.abstract: The contrast between this animated film’s grim subject matter and its bubbly animation style is a big part of what makes it so creepy, our critic writes.

multimedia.caption: “Unicorn Wars” follows two sibling bears, Bluey and Tubby, as they train for battle in the forest and ingest hallucination-inducing worms.
“Unicorn Wars” follows two sibling bears, Bluey and Tubby, as they train for battle in the forest and ingest hallucination-inducing worms.
“Unicorn Wars” follows two sibling bears, Bluey and Tubby, as they train for battle in the forest and ingest hallucination-inducing worms.

results.title: ‘Rewind & Play’ Review: Thelonious Monk Dazzles Even When an Interview Falls Flat
results.abstract: Alain Gomis’s documentary uses rushes from a 1969 French TV interview to make a smart indictment of music industry bias and offer viewers a subtle tribute to Monk.

multimedia.caption: Thelonious Monk in “Rewind & Play.”
Thelonious Monk in “Rewind & Play.”
Thelonious Monk in “Rewind & Play.”

results.title: ‘The Magic Flute’ Review: Mozart Meets C.G.I., With Help From a Tween
results.abstract: A young tenor enters a world enlivened by computer graphics at a school devoted to the composer’s works in this Roland Emmerich-inspired film.

multimedia.caption: Jack Wolfe in “The Magic Flute.”
Jack Wolfe in “The Magic Flute.”
Jack Wolfe in “The Magic Flute.”

results.title: ‘Champions’ Review: Following the Playbook
results.abstract: This film directed by Bobby Farrelly has elements that recall “Kingpin” and “There’s Something About Mary.” But the ratio of tastelessness to sentimentality has been reversed.

multimedia.caption: From left, Casey Metcalfe, James Day Keith, Woody Harrelson, Ashton Gunning and Tom Sinclair in “Champions.”
From left, Casey Metcalfe, James Day Keith, Woody Harrelson, Ashton Gunning and Tom Sinclair in “Champions.”
From left, Casey Metcalfe, James Day Keith, Woody Harrelson, Ashton Gunning and Tom Sinclair in “Champions.”

results.title: ‘Luther: The Fallen Sun’ Review: Psycho Filler
results.abstract: A smoldering Idris Elba is no match for the preposterousness of this feature-length Netflix continuation of the popular BBC crime thriller.

multimedia.caption: Idris Elba in “Luther: The Fallen Sun.”
Idris Elba in “Luther: The Fallen Sun.”
Idris Elba in “Luther: The Fallen Sun.”

results.title: Cautionary Climate Tales That Give People Pause When They Press Play
results.abstract: The India-born director Joshua Ashish Dawson builds digital worlds that ruminate on the future shock of environmental destruction in the real world.

multimedia.caption: In his short film “Denervation,” Joshua Ashish Dawson, who explores “speculative climate futures” that concern global health and the environment, imagined threats posed by counterfeiting in an unscrupulous pharmaceutical industry.

In his short film “Denervation,” Joshua Ashish Dawson, who explores “speculative climate futures” that concern global health and the environment, imagined threats posed by counterfeiting in an unscrupulous pharmaceutical industry.
